metadata.title: Effect of nano-clay de-agglomeration on mechanical properties of concrete

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Construction and Building Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /conbui ldmat
Effect of nano-clay de-agglomeration on mechanical properties of concrete
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2019.02.018 0950-0618/ 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author. E-mail address: m.kohail@eng.asu.edu.eg (M. Kohail).
Nehal Hamed a, M.S. El-Feky b, Mohamed Kohail a,⇑, El-Sayed A.R. Nasr a a Structural Engineering Department, Ain Shams University, Cairo, Egypt bDepartment of Civil Engineering, National Research Centre, Cairo, Egypt
h i g h l i g h t s
Investigate the effect of nano-clay de-agglomeration on concrete properties. The optimum percentage of dispersed nano-clay particle was recommended. Studying the effect of dispersed nano-clay on the concrete microstructure.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 18 September 2018 Received in revised form 1 February 2019 Accepted 4 February 2019
Keywords: Nano-clay Sonication De-agglomeration Mechanical properties Microstructural analysis
a b s t r a c t
This paper investigates the effect of nano-clay dispersion on concrete properties. This was extensively studied by using various percentages of nano-clay (5, 7.5, and 10%) as cement partial replacements by two ways; added as-received, added after being dispersed in water by using bath sonicator. The evaluation was based on the compressive strength, split tensile strength, flexural strength, slipping bond strength, and split bond strength of nano-clay concrete and the microstructure analysis was verified by SEM, XRD, and AFM examinations. The test results revealed that the sonication of nano-clay particles significantly enhanced concrete properties when compared to those of as-received nano-clay concrete. The optimum percentage for cement substitution by Nano-clay was found to be 7.5% for both; the asreceived, and the sonicated nano-clay. The presence of NC particles resulted in dense and wellcompacted matrix than that of the control mix as has shown in the SEM micrographs, the XRD and AFM results indicated the higher reactivity of the sonicated NC than the as-received NC.
2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Concrete is one of the most important and commonmaterials in the construction industry, Lately, many researchers have conducted deep studies to improve the environmental friendliness of concrete to make it suitable to be one of the green building materials [1–5], the most successful researches in this regard is the use of pozzolanic materials like fly ash, silica fume, and metakaolin as partial substitutes for cement resulting in reducing the cement content significantly in addition they also proved their efficiency in promoting the mechanical properties of concrete beside their friendly environment effects [5–14].
Recently, the applications of nanotechnology have become more widespread in the construction field [15], Nanotechnology is defined as the restructuring of materials to be in nano-size (less
than 150 nm) for developing new properties and functions [16]. The use of nanomaterials as partial substitutes for cement in concrete can improve its properties due to the presence of their particles in nano-size [17], and since the main hydration product of cement-based materials is C-S-H gel, is a nanostructured material [18], in addition, a number of widely spread nano-sized pores exist in the cement matrices, that make concrete a micromaterial influenced by its nano-properties.
Nanomaterials can be classified into two categories; pozzolanic as the case of (nano-silica, nano-alumina, nano-clay), and fiber like as for (carbon nanotubes and carbon nano-fiber). pozzolanic materials are characterized by their pozzolanic reactions which react with CH producing additional C-S-H gel leading to enhancing the matrices strengths [19–24], while fiber-like materials are characterized by their needle action systems due to their shapes, that could bridge the cracks and resist the propagation of cracks leading to enhancing the tensile properties of the matrix [21,22,25,26].
Nano-clay (NC) is one of the nanomaterials which researchers had focused on studying its effect on the performance of cement
mortars and concretes, recently that combines both characteristics of the nanomateraials. NC showed high pozzolanic reactivity and its particles shape which is flaky, elongated, thin, and platy which can provide the needle action system [27–36]. There are some investigations studied the effect of NC replacement on the properties of concrete (compressive, tensile, and flexural strengths) [28– 36]. However, in these studies, there were clear contradictions in determining the optimum percentage of NC replacement. Although some authors [30–33,35,36] reported that the optimum percentage of NC has to be 1% or less due to agglomeration caused by difficulties to disperse the particles during mix, others [29,34–36] stated that the enhancement of concrete properties could be directly proportional to the percentage of NC up to 10%. Some authors [30,33,36] attributed this variation to the poor dispersion of NC particles, which lead to the formation of NC agglomerations around grains of cement and hinders the hydration process of cement resulting in weak zones within the matrix.
Considering the previous studies about the agglomeration problem of nanoparticles that have a strong tendency to assemble around each other and form agglomerations as a result of van der Waals force [37], the formation of these agglomerations found to affect negatively the performance of concrete matrix [21,23,37– 39], as such, and in order to solve the nanoparticles agglomeration problem, an effective dispersion technique should be used, authors previously used various dispersion techniques such as; stirring, homogenizing and sonicating to disperse different types of nanoparticles [24,25,38–41], the sonication proved to be the most effective technique for dispersing nanoparticles in aqueous solutions, as previously reported by [23,38–42], however, there is no literature found studying the effect of NC de-agglomeration on concrete properties.
The aim of this research plan is to investigate the effect of NC particles before and after de-agglomeration on the mechanical properties of concrete and to determine the optimum NC percentage to improve the performance of concrete, the outcome of this research program will help not only in enhancing the concrete properties but also in reducing the cement quantities, and the NC quantities to be used. The reduction in the quantities of these materials will definitely reduce the CO2 footprint and increase the environmental impact of the utilized NC particles. Concrete will be examined concerning the air content, compressive strength, split tensile strength, flexural strength, and bond strength with its two behaviors of slipping and split. Also, the microstructural analysis of hardened concrete will be verified by scanning electron microscope (SEM) test, X-ray Diffraction (XRD) test and Atomic Force Microscope (AFM).

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
Ordinary Portland Cement (OPC) used in this research was (CEM I/42.5R) in accordance with ASTM C150 [43]. NC used in this research was an off-white powder. Table 1 show the chemical composition of used NC and Fig. 1 shows the TEM of NC. Natural sand is used as fine aggregates with particles size below 0.5 mm, specific gravity of 2.58 g/cm3, and fineness modulus of 2.25. Crushed clean dolomite is used as coarse aggregate of the maximum size of 12 mm and specific gravity of 2.96 g/cm3. The
mixtures aggregates consist of an incorporation of fine sand and crushed dolomite with the percentage of 35% and 65% by weight respectively. The used high range water reducer (Type G superplasticizer) is used. It is an aqueous solution of modified polycarboxylates.

sections.heading: 2.2. Mix design proportions
sections.text: In this study, seven concrete mixes were designed, control mix is made of natural aggregates, cement, water, and superplasticizer (S.P), while the NC mixes are made in the same manner but by substituting cement with different percentages of NC particles (5%, 7.5%, and 10%) by two ways; (a) using as-received NC, and (b) using NC after being sonicated in equal amount of water using indirect bath sonicator to help dispersing its particles and decrease the formation of NC agglomerations [38]. A modern ultra-sonication bath is used for NC particles dispersion with constant time, power, and frequency of 5 min, 135W, and 40 kHz respectively. The water to binder ratio is set to a steady value of 0.43 for all mixes. The mix proportions of NC concrete mixes (kg) per 1 m3 are shown in Table 2.

sections.heading: 2.3. Mixing procedure
sections.text: All concrete mixes are prepared by dry mixing the coarse aggregates, fine aggregates, and cement in a concrete turn-tilt mixer for 1.5 min, then adding NC particles after blending in a part of the mixing water for all the as-received NC mixes or after being sonicated in a part of mixing water for all the sonicated NC mixes, and then mixing for another 1 min, and finally, adding the superplasticizer with the rest of the mixing water and mixing for another 1 min.

sections.heading: 2.4. Preparation of the specimens, curing and tests
sections.text:
Evaluation of the used dispersion technique was applied on 5% NC using the Mastersizer 3000 laser diffraction particle size
analyzer. Once the concrete mixing process was finished, air content test was performed on the fresh concrete according to ASTM C231 [44]. Cubes of (100 100 100) mm3 were prepared and cast for implementing compressive strength test after 7 and 28 days of water curing according to BS EN 12390-3 [45]. Cylinders of (100 mm diameter and 200 mm in height) were prepared and cast for implementing split tensile strength test after 28 days of water curing according to ASTM C496 [46]. Prisms (50 50 200) mm3 were prepared and cast for implementing the flexural strength test after 28 days of water curing according to ASTM C293 [47]. Cubes of (150 150 150) mmwere prepared and cast for implementing the bond strength test after 28 days of water curing for steel re-bar of diameter of 12 mm and 16 mm according to RILEM 7-II-128 [48]. In order to investigate the effect of the presence of NC particles on the bond strength modes of failure, a 75 mm length of polyvinyl chloride tubing is used to de-bond the steel bar rooted inside the specimen. This makes the bond sliding failure dominates over other types of failure as like yielding of steel reinforcement, Fig. 2 shows a schematic of the pullout test specimen. For all tests, three samples were prepared for each test and the result of the test was the average results for them. Finally, three chosen samples of concrete representing the optimum percentage of as-received NC, sonicated NC, and the control mixes were examined after 56 days of water curing to study the microstructural analysis by Scanning electron microscope (SEM) test, and X-ray Diffraction (XRD) test, as for the Atomic Force Microscope (AFM), three pastes samples representing the optimum percentage of as-received NC, sonicated NC, and the control mixes were prepared and examined after 28 days of water curing.

sections.heading: 3.1. Evaluation of used dispersion techniques
sections.text:
Fig. 3 shows the Particles size distributions (P.S.D) for both; the as-received, and the sonicated NC with a concentration similar to the used in the concrete pouring process. For as-received NC, the surface area was 30.55 m2/kg and average particle size was 204 mm (size of agglomerations), while for sonicated NC, the surface area was 51050 m2/kg and average size particle was 0.13 mm (size of agglomerations).
The significant increase in the surface area, as well as, the significant reduction in the average particle size of NC after being sonicated can be attributed to the efficiency of ultra-sonication in breaking down the large agglomerates of NC particles into smaller agglomerates or even primary particles as compared to as-received NC.

sections.heading: 3.2. Air content
sections.text:
Fig. 4 shows the air content percentages of both; as-received and sonicated NC concrete. Generally, cement substitutions by either; the as-received or sonicated decreased the air content percentages for all concrete mixes when compared to the control mix (without NC).
The decreases in air content percentages were 5.6%, 11.1%, and 8.3% for cement substitution percentages of 5%, 7.5%, and 10% by as-received NC respectively. As for sonicated NC mixes, the enhancements reached 11.1%, 19.4%, and 16.7% as compared to the Co mix.
The slight decrease in air content with as-received NC can be attributed to the poor dispersion of NC particles and the forming of large agglomerates which push the cement particles away from
each other resulting in increasing the solid spaces, and consequently increase the air content relative to Sonicated NC, in addition to the air spaces already within the agglomerates.
The significant decrease in air content with Sonicated NC can be attributed to the influence of the ultra-sonication which breaks down the agglomerates into smaller agglomerates or even into singly dispersed particles and also reduce the initial particles size, leading to increasing its ability in acting like filler to the nanopores of concrete matrix, and therefore, reduce the formation of air spaces in concrete matrix relative to as-received NC.
Relative to as-received NC mixes, the air content decreased by 5.9%, 9.4%, and 9.1% for 5%, 7.5%, and 10% Sonicated NC respectively. This indicates to the efficiency of the ultra-sonication method for dispersing NC particles, de-agglomeration and ultrafine the NC particles due to the inter-particle collision.

sections.heading: 3.3. Compressive strength
sections.text:
Figs. 5 and 6 show the compressive strength results of asreceived NC and Sonicated NC concrete mixes. The cubes tested after 7 days of water curing will be referred to as 7 days compressive strength while those tested after 28 days of water curing will be referred to as 28 days compressive strength. Generally, cement substitution by either; the as-received NC, or Sonicated NC enhanced the early (7 days), and late (28 days) ages compressive strengths for all concrete mixes.
At 7 days, the highest compressive strength reached 33.0 MPa for the cement substitution by 7.5% as-received NC, while the highest compressive strength reached 41.2 MPa for the cement substitution by 7.5% Sonicated NC rather than 26.5 MPa for the control mix.
The enhancements in 7 days compressive strength for cement substitution percentages of 5%, 7.5%, and 10% by as-received NC were 18.87%, 24.52%, and 7.55% as compared to the Co mix respectively, while for Sonicated mixes, the enhancements reached 40.75%, 55.47%, and 26.04% as compared to the Co mix respectively.
At 28 days, the highest compressive strength reached 44.6 MPa for the cement substitution by 7.5% as-received NC, while the highest compressive strength at age of 28 days reached 57.2 MPa for the cement substitution by 7.5% Sonicated NC rather than 37.7 MPa for the control mix.
The enhancements in 28 days compressive strength for cement substitution percentages of 5%, 7.5%, and 10% by as-received NC were 2.65%, 18.3%, and 9.81% as compared to the Co mix respectively, as for Sonicated NC mixes, the enhancements reached 16.45%, 51.72%, and 43.24% as compared to Co mix respectively.
The compressive strength at the early, and the late ages were enhanced with increasing the cement substitution percentages by either; the as-received or the Sonicated NC up to 7.5%, and then, it was reduced with the use of 10% NC substitution, noticing that the 10% NC substitution was still higher than the Co mix. This could be possibly due to van der Waals force where increasing the number of NC particles, increased their ability to assemble around each other and form agglomerations without any chemical interactions within concrete mixes. These agglomerations form non-hydrated spots which weaken the bond among cement and aggregates, and therefore, reduce the compressive strength of concrete.
When compared to as-received NC mixes, the enhancements of compressive strength for 7 days reached (18.41%, 24.85%, and 17.19%), whereas for 28 days reached (13.44%, 28.25%, and 30.43%) for the cement substitution percentages of 5%, 7.5%, and 10% Sonicated NC respectively. This can be attributed to the influence of ultra-sonication in breaking down the agglomerates into smaller agglomerates or even into singly dispersed particles.
For the cement substitution by (5% and 7.5%) Sonicated NC, the compressive strength enhanced significantly at the early age relative to that of the Co mix. This can be attributed to; (1) the filling effect of NC particles due to its nano-size which fills the existing pores in concrete matrix and makes the matrix be well compacted, denser and uniformly restructured [30–36,49–52], (2) The high pozzolanic reactivity of NC particles which reacts with excess CH
forming extra C-S-H gel which enhances the ITZ among aggregates and cement blends resulting in promoting strengths [30– 36,49,51,53], (3) NC particles acting like a nucleus for cement hydration gels which led to forming reinforced C-S-H [32,33,36,54], while for 10% cement substitution by Sonicated NC, the slight enhancement of 28 days compressive strength was thought to be due to high particle concentration at using a steady volume of water. The high concentration results in increasing the inter-particles collision during the sonication process, whenever NC particles collide, they merge together and increase the forming of NC agglomerates. These agglomerates had low reactivity and require a prolonged time than 28 days to supplement pozzolanic reaction and react with the CH to form extra C-S-H gel and to improve the concrete strength. However, these agglomerates can still fill part of the pores within the matrix resulting in the much-compacted matrix.
The compressive strength ratios of 7 days to 28 days reached (81.4% and 74%) and (85% and 72%) for (5% and 7.5%) cement substitutions by both as-received and Sonicated NC respectively, this indicates the well dispersion of small NC particles concentrations at steady volume of water.

sections.heading: 3.4. Split tensile strength
sections.text:
Fig. 7 shows the split tensile strength results of both; the asreceived NC, and the Sonicated NC concrete. Generally, the cement substitution by either; as-received or Sonicated NC enhanced split tensile strength at 28 days for all concrete mixes. The split tensile strength results showed the same trend as the results of compressive strength.
The highest split tensile strength reached 3.6 MPa for 7.5% cement substitution by as-received NC, while for 7.5% Sonicated NC reached 4.2 MPa rather than 3.28 MPa for the control mix.
The enhancements in split tensile strength were 2.74%, 9.76%, and 4.88% for cement substitution percentages of 5%, 7.5%, and10% by as-received NC respectively, as for Sonicated NC mixes, the enhancements reached 10.67%, 28.05%, and 17.38% as compared to the Co mix. The split tensile strength enhancement for cement substitution by NC can be attributed directly to the needle action system of the NC particles as a result of the NC particles shape which is flaky, elongated, thin, and platy [33]. When tensile cracks occur in the matrix, NC platelets may inhibit and limit the propagation of the tensile micro-cracks. This performance could be seen lately in the SEM micrographs, and it was also previously referred to by Hosseini et al. [33,55]. In addition to that, the filling effect, the high pozzolanic reactivity, and nucleation effects of NC
particles which improved the compressive strength, and consequently affected the enhancement of the concrete tensile strength.
Relative to as-received NC mixes, the split tensile strength enhancements at 28 days reached 7.72%, 16.67%, and 11.92% for cement substitution percentages of 5%, 7.5%, and10% by Sonicated NC mixes respectively. The difference in the performance between the as-received NC and the Sonicated NC particles can be attributed to the effectiveness of ultra-sonication in dispersing NC particles, breaking the NC agglomerates resulting in ultrafine and high reactivity NC particles that in turn leading to increase the efficiency of NC particles regarding to the pozzolanic reactivity, nano-filling, and reinforcing the concrete matrix, and consequently, enhance the tensile strength relative to as-received NC.

sections.heading: 3.5. Flexural strength
sections.text:
Fig. 8 shows the flexural strength results of both; the asreceived and the Sonicated NC concrete mixes. In general, the cement substitution by either; as-received or Sonicated NC enhanced flexural strength at 28 days for all concrete mixes. Flexural strength results showed the same trend as the results of the compressive and split tensile strengths.
The highest flexural strength reached 10.75 MPa and 12.62 MPa for 7.5% cement substitution by as-received and Sonicated NC respectively rather than 9.35 MPa for the Co mix, the enhancements of the flexural strength reached 14.97% and 34.97% respectively as compared to the control mix.
The flexural strength enhancements were 5%, 15%, and 10% for cement substitution percentages of 5%, 7.5%, and10% by asreceived NC respectively, as for Sonicated NC mixes the flexural strength enhancements reached 15%, 35%, and 25.13% relative to the Co mix respectively.
The addition of 5% Sonicated NC had the same gain in flexural strength to the addition of 7.5% as-received NC. This indicates the efficiency of the ultra-sonication in dispersing the NC particles and breaking down the NC agglomerations resulting in forming arranged arrays in the cement based matrix as mentioned by He & Shi et al. [50], Hosseini et al. [51], and Hosseini & Vaziri et al. [55], such arranged arrays introduce a microstructural regularity into the concrete matrix via a more stable bonding framework [51], In addition, the ultra-sonication increased the ability of NC particles in; (1) acting like filler to the nanopores of concrete matrix, (2) increasing reactivity of NC particles which reacts with CH and produce an extra C-S-H gel, and (3) increasing the nucleation effect of NC particles leading to reinforcing the cement hydration, and consequently, enhance the flexural strength relative to as-received NC mixes.
When comparing the flexural strength results of Sonicated with as-received NC mixes results, it was found that the flexural strengths with the Sonicated NC mixes were enhanced by 9.5%, 17.4%, and 13.76% for cement substitution percentages of 5%, 7.5%, and 10% respectively relative to those of as-received NC mixes.

sections.heading: 3.6. Bond strength
sections.text:
As per RILEM 7-II-128, Concrete cover affects whichever behavior of the bond strength will prevail. If there is enough concrete cover around the bar (more than 4.5 the rebar diameter), the slippage behavior will occur. While in the absence of enough concrete cover (less than 4.5 the rebar diameter), the split behavior will occur [48].
Although adhesion and friction are present when a deformed bar is loaded for the first time, these bond-transfer mechanisms are quickly lost, leaving the bond to be transferred by bearing on the deformations of the bar. Equal and opposite bearing stresses act on the concrete. The forces on the concrete have both a longitudinal and a radial component. The latter causes circumferential tensile stresses in the concrete around the bar. Eventually, the concrete will split parallel to the bar, and the resulting crack will propagate out to the surface of the beam. The split cracks follow the reinforcing bars along the bottom or side surfaces of the beam, a slippage failure occurs, where the bar and the annulus of concrete between successive deformations pull out along a cylindrical failure surface joining the tips of the deformations [56], as it was confirmed by Torre-Casanova et al. [57] who presented equations for distinguishing split failure as a function of the tensile properties of concrete and for distinguishing slippage failure as a function of the compressive properties of concrete, and good agreement with M.S. El-Feky et al. [58], and N. Hamed et al. [59].

sections.heading: 3.6.1. Rebar-12 mm
sections.text:
Figs. 9–11 show the bond strength results of both; the asreceived and the Sonicated NC concrete mixes. Generally, for 12 mm re-bars specimens, the concrete cover was more than 4.5 the rebar diameter, so there were enough concrete covers and the slippage was the dominant behavior [48,56,58,59].
The slippage performance is directly affected by the compressive strength of the concrete mix, as such, the bond strength performance of 12 mm specimens followed the same trend of the compressive strength [57–59].
The highest bond strength reached 23.34 MPa and 29.62 MPa for 7.5% cement substitution by as-received and the Sonicated NC respectively rather than 19.1 MPa for the control mix, the enhancements of the bond strength reached 22.21% and 55.08% respectively as compared to the control mix.
The enhancements in bond strength were 5.55%, 22.21%, and 21.66% for cement substitution percentages of 5%, 7.5%, and 10% by ANC respectively, as for Sonicated mixes the bond strength enhancements reached 15.27%, 55.08%, and 42% relative to Co mix.
When compared to the as-received NC mixes, the gains in the bond strength with using 12 mm rebars reached (9.21%, 26.9%, and 16.43%) for the cement substitution percentages of 5%, 7.5%, and 10% by Sonicated NC respectively.

sections.heading: 3.6.2. Rebar-16 mm
sections.text:
Figs. 12–14 show the bond strength results of both; the asreceived and the Sonicated NC concrete mixes when using 16 mm rebars. In general, the split behavior occurred for all specimens of 16 mm diameter entrenched rebars in concrete (for either; the Co mix, or mixes incorporating (as-received /Sonicated) [48,56,58,59].
As per the previous discussion and since the split performance is directly affected by the tensile strength of the concrete mix, so the bond strength performance of 16 mm specimens followed the same trend of the tensile strength. The highest bond strength
reached 22.12 MPa for cement substitution by 7.5% as-received NC rather than for 21.09 MPa for Co mix (without NC).
The bond strengths enhancements were 1%, 4.88%, and 1.48% for cement substitution percentages of 5%, 7.5%, and 10% by as-
received NC respectively, as for Sonicated NC mixes, the enhancements reached 6.92%, 18.24%, and 13% respectively relative to Co mix.
While as compared to the as-received NC mixes, the enhancements in the bond strength when using 16 mm-rebar reached (5.87%, 12.75%, and 11.36%) for the cement substitution percentages of 5%, 7.5%, and 10% by Sonicated NC respectively.
For 12 mm rebars specimens, the concrete cover was more than 4.5 the rebar diameter, so there was enough concrete cover around the rebar and the slippage was the dominant behavior, while for 16 mm rebars specimens, the concrete cover was less than 4.5 the rebar diameter, so there wasn’t enough concrete cover and the split behavior was the dominant, the results are in a good agreement with Torre-Casanova et al. [57], M.S. El-Feky et al. [58], and N. Hamed et al. [59].
The improvements of bond strength with the cement substitutions by either; the as-received or the Sonicated NC can be attributed to; (1) Pozzolanic Reactivity of NC particles resulting in producing extra C-S-H gel which enhances the ITZ among aggregates and cement blends, and also enhances the bond between the steel rebar and concrete that in turn enhances the concrete strengths, (2) NC particles are acting like nucleus for cement hydration gels leading to forming reinforced C-S-H, (3) The filling effect of NC particles which resulting in the well compacted, dense and uniformly restructured matrix, and (4) needle effects of NC particles.
The bond strength was improved when increasing the cement substitution percentages by either; the as-received, or the Sonicated NC up to 7.5%, after that, it was decreased with 10% NC substitution, noticing that the 10% NC substitution was still higher than the Co mix. This can be attributed to the van der Waals force when adding a large percentage of NC particles, it assembles around each other and forms relatively large agglomerations which fail to act as filler to the nanopores within matrix and hindered its pozzolanic reactivity resulting in weakening the ITZ between aggregates and cement blends, and consequently, weaken the bond between concrete and steel rebar, and therefore, reduce the bond strength of concrete.
For 12 mm rebars, although the substitution by 7.5% Sonicated NC is one and half times higher in content than 5% Sonicated NC, the gain in bond strength for 7.5% NC (18.24%) reached 2.64 times the gain in the bond strength for 5% NC (6.92%). As for 16 mm rebars, the gain in bond strength by the substitution of 7.5% Sonicated NC (55.08%) reached 3.6 times the gain in the bond strength of 5% Sonicated NC (15.27%).

sections.heading: 3.7. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM)
sections.text:
Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) images were taken to study the micro-structure for the materials of three different specimens showing the effect of NC presence before and after being exposed to ultra-sonication relative to Co mix without NC substitution.
Figs. 15–17 show the SEM micrographs for the Co, 7.5% asreceived NC, and 7.5% Sonicated NC mixes respectively, as for the SEM plates representing the morphology and structure of the control sample relative to NC incorporated cement systems, the found structures are highly identifying the reasons behind the previously discussed mechanical properties, i.e. the Co mix showed much weaker performance in most of the mechanical properties relative to NC systems.
The ettringite needles, as well as the calcium hydroxide crystals, can be easily identified in Co mix micrograph (Fig. 15a and b), in addition to the existence of relatively large spread voids, moreover, the CSH particles are discontinued, and interfering with the calcium hydroxide crystals, and the ettringite needles resulting in
weak, highly fractured, inconsistent matrix as it can be seen in the micrographs (Fig. 15b).
While for the NC micrographs, the presence of the NC particles within cement matrix no matter sonicated or not, enhanced the consistency and homogeneity of both mixes resulting in a more compacted matrix (Figs. 16a and 17a). It can be easily recognized from the NC micrographs that the presences of NC particles lead to minimizing the void ratio within the matrix and results in a more-dense matrix. This could be due to the previously discussed filling effect where the clay nano particles fill all the nano-sized
pores, in addition to the reactivity of NC particles with the residual CH from the cement hydration process resulting in a higher amount of CSH gels (Figs. 16a and 17a).
From the as-received NC (7.5% as-received NC) micrographs, although groups of unreacted small agglomerations of the NC could be found, the matrix was still dense and compacted. These small agglomerations where found surrounded by C-S-H in a concrete spot which illustrates the nucleation site effect of the NC particles in (Fig. 16c and d), the NC particles acting like a nucleus where the cement hydration products gather around forming a
C-S-H with at least void-less core inside (in state of non-reacted NC particles due to agglomerations), while it will result in continuous solid core of high stiffness C-S-H (in state of well dispersed fully reacted NC particles).
From the sonicated NC (7.5% Sonicated) micrographs, and in addition to the dense, well compacted matrix, and the spread
Fig. 18. XRD of 7.5% as-received NC, 7.5% Soni
presence of the CSH component within the matrix, a very significant action of the NC particles was recognized, where the NC sheet-like acted as bridge connecting both sides of the crack together and preventing the propagation of the crack in a performance close to the action of fibers when arresting the cracks (Fig. 17b–d).
cated NC, and the control concrete mixes.

sections.heading: 3.8. X-ray Diffraction (XRD)
sections.text:
XRD was performed to detect changes in the hydration products due to the presence of NC before and after being exposed to ultrasonication, and relative to hydration products of a control sample without the presence of NC particles.
Fig. 18 presented the XRD peaks of the control (C), 7.5% asreceived NC, and 7.5% sonicated NC mixes, due to its crystalline nature, calcium hydroxide and calcium carbonate peaks appear clearly in the XRD diagrams, while amorphous materials such as calcium silicate hydrate cannot be directly detected by this technique [60]. The calcium hydroxide peaks could be clearly found in Co mix, while by using the NC as a cement replacement, the CH peaks decreased significantly for the mixes containing NC particles either; the as received or the sonicated. The decrease of the CH peaks directly indicates the reactivity of NC particles, and indirectly indicates higher C-S-H content in the mixes with NC substitution as a result of the reaction of the silica and aluminosilicate components in the NC with the excess calcium hydroxide (CH) from cement hydration to produce extra Calcium-SilicateHydrate (C-S-H) gel which enhances the ITZ among aggregates and cement pastes and enhances the concrete strength [60]. The 7.5% mix with sonicated NC, showed much lower peaks of the CH than the one with as-received NC particles. The calcite (CC) peaks followed the trend of the calcium hydroxide peaks, which also indicates much lesser content of CH in the mixes containing NC relative to the Co mix. The presence of the CH in large amounts ease the reaction with the CO2 in the air producing more calcite (CaCO3) as a result of the carbonation process, see Eq. (1).
Ca(OH)2 + CO2 ! CaCO3 + H2O ð1Þ As final, the mixes could be arranged in reference to the CH and CC contents as follows: 1-Co mix, 2-NC 7.5, and finally with the lowest content the Sonicated 7.5% mix.

sections.heading: 3.9. Atomic force microscope (AFM)
sections.text:
Figs. 19–21 show the topographical images from AFM of the control cement matrix (without NC), 7.5% as-received NC matrix (7.5% as-received NC), and 7.5% sonicated NC cement matrix (7.5% Sonicated NC). Although the AFM images do not have a great quantitative value other than for determination of morphology, in
this case, AFM images can be helpful for providing insight into the interpretation of the mechanical properties of NC cement matrix.
As shown in Figs. 19–21, the AFM topography images of polished cement paste incorporating NC that indicate rounded particles grouped into clumps representing the CSH aggregated particles, which supports the colloidal spheres model of C–S–H, since the spherical features observed in Figs. 20 and 21 are of similar size to the particles of the previously recognized shapes in the literature [61]. Furthermore, the clumps appear to have relatively small voids.
Taylor et al. [62] reminded us of Everett’s definition of gels as ‘‘dispersions in which the attractive interactions between the elements of the disperse phase are so strong that the whole system develops a rigid network structure and, under small stresses, behaves elastically”. C-S-H in hydrated tricalcium silicate paste exactly fits this definition. AFM imaging of the flat surface of hydrating cement paste [18,63], shows that the elements of the disperse phase occur in the forming of identical aggregated nanoparticles of C-S-H.
Images of C–S–H in hardened cement paste show nearly spherical particles of different sizes in different areas. Typical sizes of these spherical particles range reached to 465 nm for the asreceived NC cement matrix, while the range reached 721 nm for the Sonicated NC cement matrix. AFM images of C–S–H gel with brighter regions being higher than darker ones. The maximum height difference between two different points in the image of the 7.5% as-received NC matrix is 465 nm, as for the 7.5% Sonicated NC the difference reached 721 nm.
When compared to Co mix, the presence of the CH plates could be easily identified as with small clumps of the C-S-H particles, the difference between the two phases is showing, rougher, bumpy and grainy surface of the CSH compared to the smoother surface of the CH region.
The surface topography as well as the particles morphology with the wide spread of the CSH gels in the matrices containing NC relative to the Co mix, and the complete absence of the CH phases within the AFM images of 7.5% as-received NC, and 7.5% Sonicated NC mixes highly indicate the reactivity of NC particles that resulting in the previously observed tremendous mechanical properties.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The following conclusions can be drawn from the test results;
1. The NC particles enhanced all studied mechanical properties of concrete, especially when dispersed using the sonication. 2. The optimum percentage out of the studied cement substitutions was 7.5% for both; the as-received NC, and the Sonicated NC to enhance the studied mechanical properties of concrete. 3. The gains in the compressive, split tensile, flexural, and bond strengths with Sonicated NC mixes were ranged from 1.42 to 3.74 times of the gains with those of as-received NC mixes. 4. For 12 mm rebars specimens, the slippage mode of failure was the dominant behavior, while the split was dominant for 16 mm rebars specimens. 5. SEM showed the four major effect of the NC with the cement matrix; (1) filling effect, (2) pozzolanic reactivity, (3) nucleation effect, and (4) needle effect. 6. XRD and AFM results indicated the higher reactivity of Sonicated NC mixes as compared to the as-received NC mixes resulting in a denser and well compacted matrix.
Conflict of interest
The authors declared that there is no conflict of interest.

referenceMentions.context: Recently, the applications of nanotechnology have become more widespread in the construction field [15], Nanotechnology is defined as the restructuring of materials to be in nano-size (less than 150 nm) for developing new properties and functions [16].

Recently, the applications of nanotechnology have become more widespread in the construction field [15], Nanotechnology is defined as the restructuring of materials to be in nano-size (less than 150 nm) for developing new properties and functions [16].

The use of nanomaterials as partial substitutes for cement in concrete can improve its properties due to the presence of their particles in nano-size [17], and since the main hydration product of cement-based materials is C-S-H gel, is a nanostructured material [18], in addition, a number of widely spread nano-sized pores exist in the cement matrices, that make concrete a micromaterial influenced by its nano-properties.

Considering the previous studies about the agglomeration problem of nanoparticles that have a strong tendency to assemble around each other and form agglomerations as a result of van der Waals force [37], the formation of these agglomerations found to affect negatively the performance of concrete matrix [21,23,37– 39], as such, and in order to solve the nanoparticles agglomeration problem, an effective dispersion technique should be used, authors previously used various dispersion techniques such as; stirring, homogenizing and sonicating to disperse different types of nanoparticles [24,25,38–41], the sonication proved to be the most effective technique for dispersing nanoparticles in aqueous solutions, as previously reported by [23,38–42], however, there is no literature found studying the effect of NC de-agglomeration on concrete properties.

The decrease of the CH peaks directly indicates the reactivity of NC particles, and indirectly indicates higher C-S-H content in the mixes with NC substitution as a result of the reaction of the silica and aluminosilicate components in the NC with the excess calcium hydroxide (CH) from cement hydration to produce extra Calcium-SilicateHydrate (C-S-H) gel which enhances the ITZ among aggregates and cement pastes and enhances the concrete strength [60].

metadata.abstractText: This paper investigates the effect of nano-clay dispersion on concrete properties. This was extensively studied by using various percentages of nano-clay (5, 7.5, and 10%) as cement partial replacements by two ways; added as-received, added after being dispersed in water by using bath sonicator. The evaluation was based on the compressive strength, split tensile strength, flexural strength, slipping bond strength, and split bond strength of nano-clay concrete and the microstructure analysis was verified by SEM, XRD, and AFM examinations. The test results revealed that the sonication of nano-clay particles significantly enhanced concrete properties when compared to those of as-received nano-clay concrete. The optimum percentage for cement substitution by Nano-clay was found to be 7.5% for both; the asreceived, and the sonicated nano-clay. The presence of NC particles resulted in dense and wellcompacted matrix than that of the control mix as has shown in the SEM micrographs, the XRD and AFM results indicated the higher reactivity of the sonicated NC than the as-received NC. 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
